content.description:
Climb over a tricky roof sequence to the slab above.  The moves are there, you just have to find them.

The last line of bolts on the right (North) end of the crag
5 bolts and ring anchors

Climb starts on a low angle ramp attached to a blank, steep slab.

Once past the 3rd bolt you have to bring yourself onto the slab. Find good, but often reachy holds in the zig zagged cracks.

Well bolted but some falls have the potential to hit the ramp.

Far end of the crag (climbers left) of Old Goat South. 3 climbs on the same part of the wall before the trails wraps around and heads uphill to Old Goat West.
6 bolts, rings at anchor

This is actually the second pitch of Goat's Head Soup.  From the anchor, climb up onto the ridgeline, then up a series of corners to the chains.  The climbing isn't hard, but it has a great feeling of exposure high off the ground.  A 35m rope will just make it back to the ground on rappel, but I wouldn't try linking the two pitches and belaying from the ground.  There are many mid-point rappel anchors to chose from if you are rapping with a shorter rope.

Climb Goat's Head Soup (5.9) and continue up the ridgeline.  
6 bolts and ring anchors

Easy climbing up to a headwall, then some fun moves up to the anchor.  The crux is the final move before the anchor.  Second pitch is 5.7 (Dancing with Mr. D).  

Pretty much in the centre of the crag.  Look for a tall wall with lots of bolts and a few rap anchors in the middle.  This line is the obvious weakness trending left up the wall.
9 bolts and ring anchors.

Climb up the slab beside the large corner, past a series of small roofs, the last of which is the crux.  The route ends under the huge roof.

Near the left end of the crag.  The large roof above the climb is an obvious identifier.
9 bolts and ring anchors

Climbing to the 3rd bolt seemed pretty stiff for a 5.8.  Cruisy after that.

On a prominent buttress, near the far left (West) end of the crag.
6 bolts, ring anchors at top

Tenuous climbing on small, sharp holds on bad rock.  Felt considerably harder than 10b.

Line of bolts behind a small tree just right (North) of the large roof above Nubian.
6 bolts and ring anchors. They are all solid, I fell or pulled on all of them.

An awkward start leads to a rambly first half of the climb. Once you reach the prickly slab you will often be drawn right. Simply connect the reachy good holds found throughout. 

Between the last bolt and the anchor there is a left trending crack that leads to anchor. In my opinion, this is the crux. The holds are decent, although a bit slopey, and the footholds are non-existent. Manage the pump to clip the anchors. Otherwise, you can head slightly right of the crack up good jugs then traverse back to clip the anchor, considerably easier but a swinging fall would be painful on the stippled rock.

The only bolted line to the left of a large roof.
10 bolts. Rings on anchors.

Follow a shallow, low angle groove.

Far right (North) end of the crag, just before the cliff peters into nothing.
5 bolts and ring anchors
There is a small collection of bolted sport climbs on limestone typical of this area.  Most of the climbs are well bolted and on good rock, though the grading seemed a bit all over the place.
